He was a senior rebel commander of Serbian forces in [[Croatia]] during the [[Croatian War of Independence]]. MartiÄ was convicted of [[war crimes]] by the [[International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia|International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia (ICTY)]] on 12 June 2007 and sentenced to 35 years in prison. ==Biography== MartiÄ was born near Knin and was the local [[police chief]] in [[Knin]] at the time of [[Croatia]]'s [[declaration of independence]]. In 1990, he took on the position of local Serb leader, organizing ''MartiÄ's Police'' [[militia]]. From 4 January 1991 to August 1995, MartiÄ held various leadership positions, including President, Minister of Defence, Minister of Internal Affairs, in the unrecognised offices of the [[SAO Krajina|Serbian Autonomous District (SAO) Krajina]], and the [[Republic of Serbian Krajina]] (RSK). Martic was supported by [[Slobodan Milosevic]] during the 1993 presidential election in Serbian Krajina. Martic ran for the [[Serbian Party of Socialists (Croatia)|Serbian Party of Socialists]] which received significant financial support from Milosevic's [[Socialist Party of Serbia]].[http://www.scc.rutgers.edu/serbian_digest/117/t117-3.htm Milosevic Loses Krajina], Filip Svarm, December 20, 1993 Vreme News Digest Agency No 117 In a second round of voting in 1994 he was elected President and remained in power until the fall of Serbian Krajina during the Croatia's [[Operation Storm]] in 1995. Initially indicted by the [[International Criminal Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia]] (ICTY) on 25 July 1995, MartiÄ surrendered on May 15, 2002, and was transferred to the tribunal in [[The Hague]] the same day. He was charged with murder, persecutions, inhumane treatment, forced displacement, plunder of public or private property, wanton destruction of cities, towns or villages. He [[plea]]ded not guilty to all counts.{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/6743607.stm |title=Serb leader jailed for war crimes |accessdate=2007-06-12 |author= |authorlink= |date=2007-06-12 |publisher=[[BBC News]] }} According to the ICTY, in the amended indictment, he "helped organize an [[ethnic cleansing]] campaign of Croats and other non-Serbs from Krajina where 78,000 lived and virtually the entire non-Serb population was forcibly removed, deported or killed". He was originally charged only with ordering [[Zagreb rocket attack|a rocket attack]] on the Croatian capital of [[Zagreb]] which killed seven civilians as retaliation to [[Operation Flash]]. MartiÄ later appeared on Serbian television and radio, admitting he ordered the shelling. [[Milan BabiÄ]] who, along with MartiÄ, was one of the most important leaders of rebelled Croatian Serbs, said during MartiÄ's trial that the entire war in Croatia was MartiÄ's responsibility, orchestrated by [[Belgrade]].{{cite web |url=http://www.iwpr.net/?p=tri&s=f&o=259675&apc_state=henftri259753 |title=MartiÄ âProvokedâ Croatian Conflict |accessdate=2007-06-12 |author=Goran Jungvirth |date=2006-02-17 |publisher=[[Institute for War and Peace Reporting]] }} His trial started on December 13, 2005 and ended on January 12, 2007.{{cite web |url=http://www.jutarnji.hr/clanak/art-2007,6,8,martic_presuda,77793.jl |title=U utorak presuda Milanu MartiÄu |accessdate=2007-06-12 |date=2007-06-08 |publisher=[[Jutarnji list]] |language=Croatian }} On June 12, MartiÄ was sentenced to 35 years in prison.{{cite web | url = http://www.icty.org/x/cases/martic/tjug/en/070612_summary_en.pdf | format = PDF | title = Summary of Judgement for Milan MartiÄ | accessdate = 2011-05-18 | date=2007-06-12 | publisher = [[International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia]] }} His sentence of 35 years in prison was confirmed by ICTY appellate council on October 8, 2008.
